title: Human-readable duration format with i18n
description:
Implement Human() method on Duration for human-readable output with internationalization.

**API:**
```go
func (dur Duration) Human() string
func (dur Duration) Human(lang Lang) string
```

**Adaptive Granularity:**
Always show the two largest relevant units:

| Difference | EN Output | DE Output |
|------------|-----------|-----------|
| 10 months, 16 days | "10 months, 16 days" | "10 Monate, 16 Tage" |
| 2 days, 5 hours | "2 days, 5 hours" | "2 Tage, 5 Stunden" |
| 3 hours, 20 minutes | "3 hours, 20 minutes" | "3 Stunden, 20 Minuten" |
| 45 seconds | "45 seconds" | "45 Sekunden" |
| 0 | "0 seconds" | "0 Sekunden" |

**Language Support (Phase 1):**
- EN (English) - default
- DE (Deutsch) - must-have

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Human() without argument returns English
- [ ] Human(Lang) accepts language parameter
- [ ] Adaptive granularity: two largest units
- [ ] English translations complete
- [ ] German translations complete
- [ ] Zero duration handled ("0 seconds")
- [ ] Singular/plural forms correct (1 day vs 2 days)
- [ ] Unit tests for all granularity levels
- [ ] Unit tests for both EN and DE
- [ ] Benchmark meets <10µs target with i18n
- [ ] Godoc comments with examples in both languages

title: Error types and handling
description:
Define custom error types and establish error handling patterns for the library.

**Sentinel Errors:**
```go
var (
    ErrInvalidFormat   = errors.New("invalid date format")
    ErrInvalidTimezone = errors.New("invalid timezone")
    ErrOverflow        = errors.New("date overflow")
)
```

**Error Handling Principles:**
1. NEVER panic (except Must* variants)
2. Use sentinel errors for known error types
3. Wrap errors with fmt.Errorf("%w") for context
4. Return clear, actionable error messages

**Error Categories:**
- Parse errors: Invalid formats, ambiguous inputs
- Timezone errors: Unknown IANA names
- Overflow errors: Date arithmetic outside Go's time.Time range

**Documentation:**
- Document that library never panics in normal operation
- Document that Must* variants DO panic
- Provide error handling examples

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] errors.go file created
- [ ] ErrInvalidFormat defined
- [ ] ErrInvalidTimezone defined
- [ ] ErrOverflow defined
- [ ] Godoc for each error with usage context
- [ ] Documentation of no-panic policy
- [ ] Documentation of Must* panic behavior
- [ ] Example tests showing error handling patterns

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create errors.go with sentinel errors (ErrInvalidFormat, ErrInvalidTimezone, ErrOverflow), 2) Add comprehensive godoc comments for each error with usage context, 3) Document no-panic policy in package documentation, 4) Document Must* variant panic behavior, 5) Add example tests showing error handling patterns (error checking, unwrapping)

title: Timezone support and conversion
description:
Implement timezone conversion with proper DST handling.

**API:**
```go
func (d Date) In(location string) (Date, error)
```

**Behavior:**
- Convert date to specified IANA timezone
- Return error for invalid timezone names (never panic)
- Use IANA Timezone Database
- Default timezone: UTC if not specified

**DST Handling:**
Critical: `Add(1, Days)` means "same time next calendar day", NOT 24 hours
- Example: 2026-03-31 02:00 CET + 1 Day = 2026-04-01 02:00 CEST
- This is only 23 actual hours due to DST transition
- Rationale: Humans think in calendar days, not hour deltas

**Error Handling:**
- Validate IANA timezone names
- Return clear error for unknown timezones
- Return clear error for empty timezone string

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] In(location) implemented
- [ ] Uses IANA Timezone Database
- [ ] Converts to specified timezone correctly
- [ ] Invalid timezone names return error
- [ ] Empty string returns error
- [ ] Never panics on invalid input
- [ ] DST handling: Add(Days) preserves wall clock time
- [ ] Tests across DST transitions (spring and fall)
- [ ] Tests for multiple timezones (Europe/Berlin, America/New_York, etc.)
- [ ] Unit tests with 95%+ coverage
- [ ] Godoc with DST behavior clearly explained
- [ ] Example showing DST-safe arithmetic

title: Unit type and constants
description:
Define Unit type for time unit constants used in arithmetic operations.

**Technical Details:**
```go
type Unit int

const (
    Seconds Unit = iota
    Minutes
    Hours
    Days
    Weeks
    Months
    Quarters
    Years
)
```

**Design:**
- Type-safe constants (compile-time safety)
- Use iota for clear ordering
- Optional internal ParseUnit(string) for external inputs

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Unit type defined as int
- [ ] All 8 unit constants defined (Seconds through Years)
- [ ] Units use iota for ordering
- [ ] Godoc comments for Unit type and constants
- [ ] Unit tests verifying constants

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create unit.go with Unit type as int, 2) Define all 8 unit constants (Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Days, Weeks, Months, Quarters, Years) using iota, 3) Add String() method for better debugging, 4) Add comprehensive godoc comments, 5) Write unit tests verifying constants and ordering, 6) Add example tests

title: Date inspection methods
description:
Implement date inspection methods for querying metadata about a date.

**Individual Methods:**
```go
func (d Date) WeekNumber() int
func (d Date) Quarter() int
func (d Date) DayOfYear() int
func (d Date) IsWeekend() bool
func (d Date) IsLeapYear() bool
```

**Aggregated Method:**
```go
type DateInfo struct {
    WeekNumber int
    Quarter    int
    DayOfYear  int
    IsWeekend  bool
    IsLeapYear bool
    Unix       int64
}

func (d Date) Info() DateInfo
```

**Specifications:**
- **WeekNumber**: ISO 8601 (Monday first, Week 1 = first week containing Thursday)
- **Quarter**: 1-4 (Q1=Jan-Mar, Q2=Apr-Jun, Q3=Jul-Sep, Q4=Oct-Dec)
- **DayOfYear**: 1-366 (considering leap years)
- **IsWeekend**: Saturday or Sunday (not configurable in Phase 1)
- **IsLeapYear**: Divisible by 4, except centuries, except divisible by 400

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] WeekNumber() returns ISO 8601 week number
- [ ] Quarter() returns 1-4
- [ ] DayOfYear() returns 1-366
- [ ] IsWeekend() returns true for Sat/Sun
- [ ] IsLeapYear() returns true for leap years
- [ ] Info() returns struct with all fields
- [ ] ISO 8601 week compliance (Week 1 contains Thursday)
- [ ] Leap year rules correct (4, 100, 400 rule)
- [ ] Unit tests for all methods
- [ ] Edge cases: year boundaries, week 53, leap years
- [ ] Benchmarks meet <1µs target
- [ ] Godoc for each method with conventions documented

title: Format presets and constants
description:
Implement preset format constants and Format() method.

**API:**
```go
type Format int

const (
    ISO Format = iota     // "2026-02-09"
    EU                    // "09.02.2026"
    US                    // "02/09/2026"
    Long                  // "February 9, 2026" (language-dependent)
    RFC2822               // "Mon, 09 Feb 2026 00:00:00 +0000"
)

func (d Date) Format(format Format) string
```

**Language Dependency:**
- ISO, EU, US, RFC2822: Always language-independent
- Long: Uses Lang setting
  - EN: "February 9, 2026"
  - DE: "9. Februar 2026"

**Implementation:**
- Map Format constants to Go layout strings
- Use Lang() setting for Long format
- Delegate to time.Format() internally

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Format type and constants defined
- [ ] Format() method implemented
- [ ] ISO format outputs "YYYY-MM-DD"
- [ ] EU format outputs "DD.MM.YYYY"
- [ ] US format outputs "MM/DD/YYYY"
- [ ] RFC2822 format correct
- [ ] Long format respects Lang setting (EN and DE)
- [ ] Non-Long formats ignore Lang setting
- [ ] Unit tests for all formats
- [ ] Unit tests for Long with both EN and DE
- [ ] Benchmark meets <5µs without i18n, <10µs with i18n
- [ ] Godoc for each format constant
- [ ] Example tests showing each format

title: CI/CD pipeline setup
description:
Set up GitHub Actions CI/CD pipeline for automated testing and quality checks.

**CI Workflow:**
- Run on push and pull requests
- Test on multiple Go versions (1.22, 1.23, latest)
- Test on multiple platforms (Linux, macOS, Windows)
- Run go fmt check
- Run go vet
- Run tests with coverage
- Run benchmarks (informational)
- Optional: golangci-lint

**Coverage Reporting:**
- Generate coverage report
- Fail if coverage <95% for core calculation functions
- Optional: Upload to codecov.io or similar

**Performance Monitoring:**
- Run benchmarks on each commit
- Report benchmark results (informational, no fail)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] .github/workflows/ci.yml created
- [ ] Tests run on push and PR
- [ ] Multi-version Go support (1.22+)
- [ ] Multi-platform support (Linux, macOS, Windows)
- [ ] go fmt check passes
- [ ] go vet check passes
- [ ] Tests run with coverage report
- [ ] Coverage requirement enforced (95%+)
- [ ] Benchmarks run (informational)
- [ ] CI badge in README (if applicable)

**README.md Contents:**

title: MustParse convenience function
description:
Implement MustParse() convenience function that panics on error (for tests/initialization).

**API:**
```go
func MustParse(s string) Date
```

**Behavior:**
- Calls Parse() internally
- Returns Date on success
- Panics on error (with clear panic message)

**Use Cases:**
- Test fixtures
- Static initialization
- Configuration files where values are known-good

**Documentation:**
- MUST clearly document that this function panics
- MUST recommend using Parse() in production code
- MUST show test usage examples

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] MustParse() implemented
- [ ] Returns Date on successful parse
- [ ] Panics with clear message on error
- [ ] Godoc clearly warns about panic behavior
- [ ] Godoc recommends Parse() for production
- [ ] Example test showing test fixture usage
- [ ] Unit tests verifying panic on invalid input

title: Project setup and structure
description:
Set up initial project structure, module, and tooling.

**Repository Structure:**
```
quando/
├── quando.go           # Package-level functions
├── date.go             # Date type and core methods
├── arithmetic.go       # Add, Sub
├── snap.go             # StartOf, EndOf, Next, Prev
├── diff.go             # Duration type, Diff
├── inspect.go          # WeekNumber, Quarter, etc.
├── format.go           # Formatting
├── parse.go            # Parsing
├── clock.go            # Clock abstraction
├── i18n.go             # Internationalization
├── errors.go           # Error types
├── internal/calc/      # Internal helpers
├── *_test.go           # Unit tests
├── example_test.go     # Godoc examples
├── bench_test.go       # Benchmarks
├── go.mod
├── go.sum
├── README.md
├── LICENSE             # MIT

```

**Go Module:**
- Module path: code.beautifulmachines.dev/quando
- Go version: 1.22+
- Zero dependencies (stdlib only)

**Tooling:**
- go fmt
- go vet
- golangci-lint (optional)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Go 1.22+ specified in go.mod

title: Custom layout formatting
description:
Implement FormatLayout() for custom format layouts using Go's standard layout format.

**API:**
```go
func (d Date) FormatLayout(layout string) string
```

**Behavior:**
- Uses Go's reference date format (Mon Jan 2 15:04:05 MST 2006)
- Respects Lang() setting for month/weekday names
- Delegates to time.Format() with translations applied

**Examples:**
```go
// English (default)
date.FormatLayout("Monday, 2. January 2006")
// → "Monday, 9. February 2026"

// German
date.Lang(LangDE).FormatLayout("Monday, 2. January 2006")
// → "Montag, 9. Februar 2026"
```

**Implementation:**
- Replace month/weekday names based on Lang setting
- Handle both full and abbreviated names
- Preserve all other layout characters

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] FormatLayout() implemented
- [ ] Uses Go's standard layout format
- [ ] Default (EN) outputs English month/weekday names
- [ ] DE lang outputs German month/weekday names
- [ ] Full names translated (Monday, January)
- [ ] Abbreviated names translated (Mon, Jan)
- [ ] Non-date characters preserved in layout
- [ ] Unit tests for various layouts
- [ ] Unit tests for both EN and DE
- [ ] Benchmark meets <10µs target with i18n
- [ ] Godoc with Go layout format reference
- [ ] Example tests showing custom layouts

title: Snap operations: Next and Prev weekday
description:
Implement Next and Prev methods to jump to next/previous occurrence of a weekday.

**API:**
```go
func (d Date) Next(weekday time.Weekday) Date
func (d Date) Prev(weekday time.Weekday) Date
```

**Critical Behavior:**
- **Next(Monday)**: Always NEXT Monday, never today (even if today is Monday)
- **Prev(Friday)**: Always PREVIOUS Friday, never today (even if today is Friday)
- Preserves time of day from source date

**Examples:**
- Monday calling Next(Monday) → next Monday (7 days later)
- Monday calling Prev(Monday) → previous Monday (7 days earlier)
- Tuesday calling Next(Monday) → next Monday (6 days later)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Next() implemented for all weekdays
- [ ] Prev() implemented for all weekdays
- [ ] Next() never returns today (always future)
- [ ] Prev() never returns today (always past)
- [ ] Time of day preserved from source
- [ ] Edge case: Same weekday correctly skips to next/prev week
- [ ] Unit tests for all weekday combinations
- [ ] Tests for same weekday edge case
- [ ] Benchmarks meet <1µs target
- [ ] Godoc comments with same-weekday behavior example

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Add Next(weekday) and Prev(weekday) methods to snap.go, 2) Implement logic to ALWAYS skip to next/prev occurrence (never return today), 3) Preserve time of day from source date, 4) Handle same-weekday edge case (Monday.Next(Monday) = next Monday), 5) Write comprehensive unit tests for all weekday combinations, 6) Add tests specifically for same-weekday edge case, 7) Add benchmarks, 8) Ensure godoc comments with examples

title: Arithmetic operations: Add and Sub
description:
Implement Add and Sub methods for all time units with special month-end overflow handling.

**API:**
```go
func (d Date) Add(value int, unit Unit) Date
func (d Date) Sub(value int, unit Unit) Date
```

**Critical Requirements:**
- Support all 8 units (Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Days, Weeks, Months, Quarters, Years)
- **Month-end overflow**: When adding months, if target day doesn't exist, snap to month end
  - 2026-01-31 + 1 month = 2026-02-28 (February end)
  - 2026-01-24 + 1 month = 2026-02-24 (regular)
  - 2026-05-31 + 1 month = 2026-06-30 (June has 30 days)
- DST handling: Add(1, Days) = same time next calendar day, NOT 24 hours
- Support method chaining (fluent API)
- Immutability: return new Date, never modify receiver

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Add() implemented for all 8 units
- [ ] Sub() implemented for all 8 units
- [ ] Month-end overflow logic correct for all month combinations
- [ ] Leap year handling (Feb 29 edge cases)
- [ ] DST handling tested across DST transitions
- [ ] Negative values supported (Add(-1) == Sub(1))
- [ ] Method chaining works (Add().Sub().Add())
- [ ] Unit tests with 95%+ coverage
- [ ] Table-driven tests for month-end edge cases
- [ ] Benchmarks meet <1µs target
- [ ] Godoc comments with month-end examples

title: Snap operations: StartOf and EndOf
description:
Implement StartOf and EndOf methods to jump to beginning/end of time units.

**API:**
```go
func (d Date) StartOf(unit Unit) Date
func (d Date) EndOf(unit Unit) Date
```

**Supported Units:** Week, Month, Quarter, Year

**Behavior:**
- **StartOf(Week)**: Monday 00:00:00 (ISO 8601 default)
- **EndOf(Week)**: Sunday 23:59:59
- **StartOf(Month)**: 1st day of month, 00:00:00
- **EndOf(Month)**: Last day of month, 23:59:59
- **StartOf(Quarter)**: Q1=Jan 1, Q2=Apr 1, Q3=Jul 1, Q4=Oct 1
- **EndOf(Quarter)**: Q1=Mar 31, Q2=Jun 30, Q3=Sep 30, Q4=Dec 31
- **StartOf(Year)**: Jan 1, 00:00:00
- **EndOf(Year)**: Dec 31, 23:59:59

**Quarter Definition:**
- Q1 = January–March
- Q2 = April–June
- Q3 = July–September
- Q4 = October–Dezember

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] StartOf(Week) returns Monday 00:00:00
- [ ] EndOf(Week) returns Sunday 23:59:59
- [ ] StartOf(Month) returns 1st day 00:00:00
- [ ] EndOf(Month) handles all month lengths correctly
- [ ] StartOf(Quarter) returns correct quarter start
- [ ] EndOf(Quarter) returns correct quarter end (handles 30/31 day months)
- [ ] StartOf(Year) returns Jan 1 00:00:00
- [ ] EndOf(Year) returns Dec 31 23:59:59
- [ ] Leap year handling for February
- [ ] Unit tests for all units and edge cases
- [ ] ISO 8601 week compliance tests
- [ ] Benchmarks meet <1µs target
- [ ] Godoc comments with examples

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create snap.go with StartOf() and EndOf() methods, 2) Implement Week snapping (Monday start, Sunday end per ISO 8601), 3) Implement Month snapping (handle all month lengths), 4) Implement Quarter snapping (Q1=Jan-Mar, Q2=Apr-Jun, Q3=Jul-Sep, Q4=Oct-Dec), 5) Implement Year snapping, 6) Add comprehensive unit tests (all units, edge cases, leap years, month-end variations), 7) Add benchmarks to meet <1µs target, 8) Add godoc comments and example tests

title: Automatic date parsing
description:
Implement automatic parsing that detects common date formats without explicit layout.

**API:**
```go
func Parse(s string) (Date, error)
```

**Supported Formats:**
- ISO: "2026-02-09"
- ISO with slash: "2026/02/09"
- EU (dot separator): "09.02.2026"
- RFC2822: "Mon, 09 Feb 2026 00:00:00 +0000"

**Ambiguity Rules:**
Slash formats without year prefix are AMBIGUOUS and must error:

| Input | Recognition | Reason |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| 2026-02-01 | ✅ ISO | Standard format |
| 01.02.2026 | ✅ EU | Dot = EU convention |
| 2026/02/09 | ✅ ISO | Year prefix unambiguous |
| 01/02/2026 | ❌ ERROR | Ambiguous (US vs EU) |

**Error Handling:**
- Return clear error for ambiguous formats
- Return clear error for invalid dates
- Never panic

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Parse() implemented
- [ ] ISO format recognized (YYYY-MM-DD)
- [ ] ISO slash format recognized (YYYY/MM/DD)
- [ ] EU format recognized (DD.MM.YYYY)
- [ ] RFC2822 format recognized
- [ ] Ambiguous slash formats return error
- [ ] Invalid dates return error
- [ ] Never panics on any input
- [ ] Unit tests for all supported formats
- [ ] Unit tests for ambiguous/invalid inputs
- [ ] Benchmark meets <10µs target
- [ ] Godoc with ambiguity rules documented
- [ ] Example tests showing supported formats

title: Core infrastructure: Date type and conversions
description:
Implement the core Date type that wraps time.Time and provides the foundation for the fluent API.

**Technical Details:**
- `Date` struct with private `time.Time` field and optional `Lang` field
- Package-level constructors: `Now()`, `From(time.Time)`
- Conversion methods: `Time()` returns underlying time.Time
- Unix timestamp support: `Unix()` and `FromUnix(int64)`

**Implementation Notes:**
- Date must wrap time.Time, not reimplement it
- All operations return new Date instances (immutability)
- Support full Go time.Time range (year 0-9999+)
- Support negative Unix timestamps (before 1970)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Date struct defined with time.Time and Lang fields
- [ ] Now() returns current date
- [ ] From(time.Time) converts to Date
- [ ] Time() extracts underlying time.Time
- [ ] Unix() returns Unix timestamp (int64)
- [ ] FromUnix(int64) creates Date from timestamp
- [ ] Unit tests with 95%+ coverage
- [ ] Godoc comments for all exported types/functions
- [ ] Example tests in example_test.go

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create date.go with Date struct (t time.Time, lang Lang), 2) Implement package-level constructors Now() and From(time.Time), 3) Add conversion methods Time(), Unix(), FromUnix(), 4) Create quando.go for package-level exports, 5) Write comprehensive unit tests covering edge cases (negative Unix timestamps, full time.Time range), 6) Add example tests in example_test.go, 7) Ensure all exports have godoc comments

title: Duration type and Diff calculation
description:
Implement Duration type and Diff function for calculating differences between dates.

**API:**
```go
func Diff(a, b time.Time) Duration

type Duration struct {
    // private fields
}

// Integer methods (rounded down)
func (dur Duration) Seconds() int64
func (dur Duration) Minutes() int64
func (dur Duration) Hours() int64
func (dur Duration) Days() int
func (dur Duration) Weeks() int
func (dur Duration) Months() int
func (dur Duration) Years() int

// Float methods (precise)
func (dur Duration) MonthsFloat() float64
func (dur Duration) YearsFloat() float64
```

**Precision:**
- Integer variants return rounded-down values
- Float variants for precise calculations
- Handle negative differences (date1 < date2)
- Cross year boundaries correctly
- Handle leap years correctly

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Duration type defined
- [ ] Diff(a, b) returns Duration
- [ ] All integer methods implemented (Seconds through Years)
- [ ] Float methods for Months and Years implemented
- [ ] Negative differences handled correctly
- [ ] Calculations correct across year boundaries
- [ ] Leap year handling correct
- [ ] Unit tests with 95%+ coverage
- [ ] Table-driven tests for various date ranges
- [ ] Benchmarks meet <1µs (int) and <2µs (float) targets
- [ ] Godoc comments with precision explanation

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create diff.go with Duration type (private fields: start, end time.Time), 2) Implement Diff(a, b) package function, 3) Implement integer methods (Seconds through Years) with rounded-down values, 4) Implement float methods (MonthsFloat, YearsFloat) for precise calculations, 5) Handle negative differences (when a < b), 6) Correctly handle year boundaries and leap years in month/year calculations, 7) Write comprehensive table-driven tests covering edge cases, 8) Add benchmarks, 9) Godoc comments with precision explanation

Ensure comprehensive test coverage (95%+) and performance benchmarks for all features.

**Test Requirements:**

title: Relative date parsing
description:
Implement ParseRelative for parsing relative date expressions.

**API:**
```go
func ParseRelative(s string) (Date, error)
```

**Supported Expressions (Phase 1):**
- "today" → Today 00:00:00
- "tomorrow" → Tomorrow 00:00:00
- "yesterday" → Yesterday 00:00:00
- "+2 days" → Today + 2 days
- "-1 week" → Today - 1 week
- "+3 months" → Today + 3 months

**Format:**
- Relative offsets: [+|-]<number> <unit>
- Units: day(s), week(s), month(s), quarter(s), year(s)
- Singular and plural forms supported

**Out of Scope (Phase 1):**
- Complex expressions ("next monday", "start of month")
- These are nice-to-have for later versions

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] ParseRelative() implemented
- [ ] "today" returns today 00:00:00
- [ ] "tomorrow" returns tomorrow 00:00:00
- [ ] "yesterday" returns yesterday 00:00:00
- [ ] "+N <unit>" adds N units to today
- [ ] "-N <unit>" subtracts N units from today
- [ ] Singular and plural units both work
- [ ] All Phase 1 units supported (days, weeks, months, quarters, years)
- [ ] Invalid expressions return clear errors
- [ ] Never panics
- [ ] Unit tests for all supported expressions
- [ ] Unit tests for invalid inputs
- [ ] Benchmark meets <20µs target
- [ ] Godoc with supported expressions listed
- [ ] Note about future complex expressions

title: Clock abstraction for testability
description:
Implement Clock interface to enable dependency injection and deterministic testing.

**Technical Details:**
```go
type Clock interface {
    Now() Date
    From(t time.Time) Date
}
```

**Implementations:**
- DefaultClock: Uses time.Now()
- FixedClock: Returns fixed time for tests

**API:**
- `NewClock()` - returns DefaultClock
- `NewFixedClock(time.Time)` - returns FixedClock for tests

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clock interface defined
- [ ] DefaultClock implementation using time.Now()
- [ ] FixedClock implementation with fixed time
- [ ] NewClock() factory function
- [ ] NewFixedClock(time.Time) factory function
- [ ] Unit tests demonstrating deterministic test patterns
- [ ] Godoc comments
- [ ] Example test showing test usage pattern

comments.author: Oliver Jakoubek
comments.text: Plan: 1) Create clock.go with Clock interface (Now, From methods), 2) Implement DefaultClock using time.Now(), 3) Implement FixedClock with fixed time for deterministic tests, 4) Add factory functions NewClock() and NewFixedClock(time.Time), 5) Write comprehensive unit tests demonstrating deterministic test patterns, 6) Add example tests showing test usage, 7) Ensure all exports have godoc comments

title: Explicit parsing with layout
description:
Implement explicit parsing using Go's standard layout format.

**API:**
```go
func ParseWithLayout(s, layout string) (Date, error)
```

**Purpose:**
Handle ambiguous or custom formats by providing explicit layout

**Examples:**
```go
ParseWithLayout("01/02/2026", "02/01/2006")  // EU format
ParseWithLayout("01/02/2026", "01/02/2006")  // US format
ParseWithLayout("9. Februar 2026", "2. January 2006")  // German custom
```

**Implementation:**
- Delegate to time.Parse() with layout
- Wrap result in quando.Date
- Return clear errors for invalid inputs

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] ParseWithLayout() implemented
- [ ] Uses Go's standard layout format (reference date)
- [ ] Wraps time.Parse() correctly
- [ ] Returns Date on success
- [ ] Returns error on parse failure
- [ ] Never panics
- [ ] Unit tests for various layouts
- [ ] Unit tests for invalid inputs
- [ ] Benchmark meets <10µs target
- [ ] Godoc with Go layout format explanation
- [ ] Example tests showing EU vs US disambiguation

title: Language constants and i18n infrastructure
description:
Define language constants and i18n infrastructure for multi-language support.

**API:**
```go
type Lang string

const (
    LangEN Lang = "en"  // English (Default)
    LangDE Lang = "de"  // Deutsch
)

func (d Date) Lang(lang Lang) Date  // Fluent API
```

**Phase 1 Languages:**
- EN (English) - default
- DE (Deutsch) - must-have

**i18n Applies To:**
- Format(Long) - "February 9, 2026" vs "9. Februar 2026"
- Custom layouts with month/weekday names
- Human() duration format

**i18n Does NOT Apply To:**
- ISO, EU, US, RFC2822 formats (always language-independent)
- Numeric outputs (WeekNumber, Quarter, etc.)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Lang type defined as string
- [ ] LangEN and LangDE constants defined
- [ ] Lang() method on Date for fluent API
- [ ] Month names in EN and DE
- [ ] Weekday names in EN and DE
- [ ] Time unit names for Human() in EN and DE
- [ ] Unit tests for language switching
- [ ] Godoc comments
- [ ] Documentation noting future language expansion (21 more)
